title: Blasts, Blazes Shake Saudi Oil Town’s Inhabitants
text:
ABQAIQ, Saudi Arabia—A series of massive explosions started around 3 a.m. Saturday, turning the sprawling crude-oil hub here into an inferno that illuminated the desert sky and sent residents of this small town fleeing for the safety of the sands.

As plumes of thick, black smoke billowed from the Abqaiq oil facility, emergency services raced to contain fires at multiple locations, witnesses said.

By Sunday afternoon, thin wisps of smoke still remained in the air, visible for miles on approach into the town.

Abqaiq is the world’s biggest facility of its kind. It processes seven million barrels of Saudi oil a day, drawing crude from the kingdom’s massive oil fields and separating it from gas into specific grades. Those, such as Arabian Extra Light, are then exported around the globe.

U.S. officials have accused Iran of orchestrating an attack on the Abqaiq facility and another at the Khurais oil field, one of the kingdom’s largest. The assaults have suspended production of 5.7 million barrels of Saudi oil a day, more than half of the country’s output, and raised tensions in the Middle East.

Iran’s Foreign Ministry on Sunday denied any involvement. Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who the U.S. says are supported by Iran, have taken responsibility.

Attacks have plagued the Abqaiq facility before. In 2006, al Qaeda mounted a failed assault on the site using suicide bombers and sent oil prices at the time more than $2 a barrel higher.

But Saturday’s attack was more damaging, causing at least six separate blazes at the facility, some which grew to more than 30 feet tall, according to witnesses.

Galahad, a Filipino worker at a pizza store, said he and his six housemates got in a car at about 5 a.m. and raced to safety in the desert, concerned about how many buildings would catch fire in the town. “We were very scared,” he said.

More than 70% of Saudi Arabia’s daily oil production runs through Abqaiq before it gets sent into a network of pipelines heading for Saudi ports.

Then it is shipped off to China, India, the U.S. and other markets.

“If you want to attack one location that has the highest percentage of oil going into the global market, that would be it,” said Ellen Wald, the president of Transversal Consulting and author of “Saudi Inc.,” a corporate history of the kingdom.

Abqaiq itself is a sparsely populated desert community with little to offer beyond a giant oil facility, visibly divided between the facilities of Aramco, the Saudi oil company, and the rest of town.

It lies north of the Empty Quarter, a 250,000-square-mile expanse that is one of the longest continuous deserts in the world.

A few thousand Aramco employees are housed in a residential compound, which has tennis courts, a swimming pool and golf course.

Outside the compound, Saudis and foreign workers from South Asia and the Philippines live in dilapidated houses surrounded by gates and high walls, a common Saudi style.

Residents who spoke to The Wall Street Journal in Abqaiq conceded that it was difficult to ascertain what happened early Sunday, but two people said they had viewed a drone in the sky above the burning plant and one said he had heard gunfire targeted at the unmanned vehicle.

In one video that an Abqaiq resident showed The Wall Street Journal, flames dozens of feet high can be seen blazing at the facility as the sounds of the fajr, the predawn Islamic call to prayer, are heard in the background.

“I didn’t know whether it was an attack or an accident,” said one Egyptian worker who was woken by booming sound and went outside to film the scene. He saw six to eight separate fires raging at the Abqaiq site, less than a mile from his residence.

The manager of a burger chain near the Aramco compound said he was cleaning and closing up for the night when an explosion rang out so loud, and seemingly close, that he thought a burglar was attempting to break into the store.

He said his wife then called and screamed: “Come back, come back!” He dashed home to drive his family out of the city.

Write to Rory Jones at rory.jones@wsj.com
description: The sprawling crude hub of Abqaiq turned into an inferno that illuminated the desert sky and sent residents of the small town fleeing for the safety of the sands.
